subject: Re: JUnit with SAX Parser Error
msgSnippet: Thanks Peter and Krishna, Sorry I didn t find all the previous postings on this - I m new to the group and there are a lot of past messages! The need to rerun
messageBody:
Thanks Peter and Krishna,

Sorry I didn't find all the previous postings on this - I'm new to
the group and there are a lot of past messages!

The need to rerun the tests is a small price to pay for all the
benefits of JUnit but, since the problem did not occur with version
3.2 I wonder if anything could be done to fix it?

Thanks for the help,

Simon.

--- In junit@y..., kumar@b... wrote:
> Hi,
>
> If you dont want all that jazz of the gui runner and the nice tree
of
> tests that it delivers, use the textui runner , it has no problems
> running the tests, and the linkage error will go whooosh!!
> me hv tried on 3.6,3.5,3.7
>
> cheers
> Krishna
>
>
>
> --- In junit@y..., Peter Spitz <pspitz@i...> wrote:
> > I ran into this when moving from JUnit 3.2 to 3.5.
> >
> > Specifying the -noloading parameter when running the Swing GUI
> fixed it. It
> > has to do with the class loader. I'm no expert so I can't explain
> it but
> > there are lots of other people in this group who can.
> >
> > The only problem is that you have to restart the tests if you
change
> > anything and want to rerun them. You can't just click the run
> button again
> > because the changed classes will not load. I consider this a
small
> price to
> > pay for the ability to run the tests.
> >
> > If you search the archive of this group, you'll find lots of
> explanations of
> > why this happens. Look for -noloading.
> >
> > Hope this helps,
> > Peter

> >
> > When we try to apply JUnit to a test class which reads from an
XML
> > document it appears that JUnit applies a custom class loader
> > (junit.runner.TestCaseClassLoader) which is then violated by the
> SAX
> > parser (a linkage error is thrown related to the JVM security).
It
> > seems that the JUnit class loader is setting the security on the
> JVM
> > to be too restrictive. The full stack trace appears below.
> >
> > This problem occurs with versions 3.6 and 3.7 of JUnit (with both
> the
> > Xerces and JAXP parsers). It does not occur with version 3.2 of
> JUnit
> > (we have not tried with any between 3.2 and 3.6).
> >
> > Has anyone had a similar problem (or successfully used a JUnit
3.6
> or
> > 3.7 test class with a SAX parser)?
> >
> > Can anyone suggest a workaround (prefereably not reverting to
> 3.2!).
> > We are quite new to JUnit and this is the first seemingly major
> > problem we have encountered.
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > Simon.
